content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Search for the one-way flight available from Calgary to New York on May 1st, 2026 with the lowest carbon dioxide emissions.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to change the departure city from "Toronto" to "Calgary" for the search. The departure input box for the city is labeled [13].
Action: Type [13]; Calgary
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure city is now set to Calgary. Next, I need to input "New York" as the destination city in the "Where to?" textbox labeled [14].
Action: Type [14]; New York
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination is now set to New York. Next, I need to set the departure date to May 1st, 2026 by interacting with the "Departure" input, which was [15] in the previous screen (now replaced with [17]).
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently displaying dates for September and October. Since I need to select May 1st, 2026, I should navigate forward by clicking "Next" ([74]) multiple times to reach May 2026.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently showing October and November. I need to continue clicking "Next" ([75]) to advance further to reach May 2026.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.28
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is showing November and December. To reach May 2026, I need to keep clicking the "Next" button ([75]) to advance to later months.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now showing December and January 2026. Since I need to get to May 2026, I should keep advancing by clicking "Next" ([76]).
Action: Click [76]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.33
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now showing January and February 2026. I need to continue advancing through the months to reach May 2026 by clicking "Next" ([73]).
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.36
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now showing February and March 2026. I still need to navigate further to reach May 2026. I should continue clicking the "Next" button ([73]).
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.39
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now showing March and April 2026. I still need to advance one more time to reach May 2026. I should click the "Next" button ([75]) again.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.42
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays May 2026. I need to select May 1st, which is labeled [43] ("1$585"), to set it as the departure date for the flight search.
Action: Click [43]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: May 1st, 2026 is selected as the departure date. I now need to confirm the date selection by clicking the "Done" button labeled [79], which will proceed to showing the available flights for that date.
Action: Click [79]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure and destination cities are set but the flight is still set to "Round trip" rather than "One way." I need to change the trip type to "One way" by interacting with the "Round trip" button ([10]) before searching.
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.65

content:
Thought: I need to identify the one-way flight from Calgary to New York on May 1, 2026, with the lowest carbon dioxide emissions. The emissions values are clearly labeled for each listed flight: 337 kg CO2e ([42] and [59]) and 412 kg CO2e ([76]). The lowest value is 337 kg CO2e. There are two flights with 337 kg CO2e emissions: the Air Canada nonstop flight departing at 7:15 AM ([33]) and the United/Air Canada 1-stop flight at 12:30 PM ([49]), with the Air Canada nonstop being the most direct and earliest.

Action: ANSWER; The one-way flight from Calgary to New York on May 1st, 2026, with the lowest carbon dioxide emissions is the Air Canada nonstop flight departing at 7:15 AM and arriving at 1:48 PM at Newark (EWR), with emissions of 337 kg CO2e. Price: CA$327.
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
